meta.title: Delay, Deny, Defend: Why Insurance Companies Don't Pay Claims and What You Can Do About It
meta.author: Jay M. Feinman

parts.title: Introduction to Insurance Issues
parts.body: The introduction of the book discusses how insurance is crucial for protecting the financial security of the middle class in America. It describes insurance as a promise provided in exchange for a premium. However, the book highlights a common issue with how insurance companies often fail to uphold this promise through tactics known as "delay, deny, defend," where they delay payments, deny valid claims, or defend aggressively in lawsuits. The author aims to establish the prevalence of this issue and encourage steps towards fair claim settlements.

parts.title: Moral Hazard and Trust in Insurance
parts.body: Insurance companies must honor their promise to pay claims promptly and fairly. Moral hazard arises when insured individuals behave recklessly because they know they're protected. Economist Kenneth Arrow suggested that insured people might use more health services, raising costs. Arrow argued that morality and economic behavior aren't separate; trust is essential. In principal-agent relationships, one party impacts the other, and both must act responsibly for insurance to work effectively.

parts.title: Insurance Claims Transformation
parts.body: McKinsey & Company played a significant role in transforming how insurance companies handle claims. Traditionally, claims adjusters used autonomy to assess claims fairly based on policies. In the 1980s, pressures for cost efficiency led companies to manage expenses more aggressively. In the 1990s, McKinsey redefined claims handling, targeting leakage where more was paid than necessary, thus making claims a profit center rather than just fair settlements. The focus shifted to reducing payouts to boost profits, rather than promptly paying fair amounts.

parts.title: The Downfall of the Independent Claims Adjuster
parts.body: Claims Adjusters: Once seen as essential, front-line claims adjusters used to manage entire claims processes. They assessed coverage, investigated, negotiated, and worked with lawyers, embodying brains, integrity, and guts. Now, adjuster roles have shifted due to systematic changes prioritizing corporate profits. Adjusters rely heavily on systems that limit discretion. Their performance is judged on conformity, focusing on economic outcomes for the company rather than fairness to customers. Adjuster's Role Evolution: Adjusters now act more like clerks than independent professionals. Systems measure and evaluate adjusters based on compliance and cost-saving outcomes. This systemic change pushes for profit-driven evaluations over individual claim assessments. Adjusters adhering tightly to systems, sometimes find their discretion and judgment criticized, skewing fairness and customer-centric values in favor of aligning with profit objectives. The claim process's focus now prioritizes systematic operations, often at the expense of accuracy and fairness.

parts.title: Insurance Company Claims Handling
parts.body: Insurance companies have a duty to their policyholders, indirectly helping third-party claimants. If a company doesn't settle in good faith, they might face a lawsuit for excess losses and even punitive damages. This duty benefits claimants if policyholders can't afford judgments unless insurance pays. Cases show how companies violate obligations — from stonewalling in Priscilla Young’s case, where the company rejected compensation offers, to hardball litigation tactics. Examples include overwhelming the plaintiff with excessive interrogatories and repeated discovery, aiming to deter pursuit of just claims. On MIST claims (minor impact soft tissue), insurance companies initially identified opportunities to reduce payments. These include whiplash and connective tissue issues, historically disputed and hard to diagnose. New strategies focused on aggressive defense, sometimes leading to claims being Closed Without Payment (CWP). A compromise isn't desired, pushing litigation costs to discourage claimants. Companies aim to show that minor accidents shouldn't cause significant injuries. The tactics pressure unrepresented victims into minimal settlements and pressure attorneys to drop small cases, exploiting the economics of legal practice. Allstate and other companies train staff for assertive defenses, illustrating a systematic approach against MIST claims, impacting overall settlement amounts.

parts.title: Complexities and Challenges of Homeowners Insurance
parts.body: Homeowners insurance, initially based on Lloyd’s policies, has evolved over centuries, starting from marine insurance to comprehensive homeowners insurance in the 1940s that covers both property loss and liability. Most homeowners in coverage today use complex policies like HO-3, filled with complicated definitions and exclusions. The disorder and complexity of these policies often lead to misinterpretations. Homeowners largely rely on insurance adjusters to understand policies due to this complexity. Nonetheless, misuse by adjusters, whether intentional or inadvertent, can result in homeowners not obtaining the full benefits of their policies.

parts.title: State Farm's Handling of Claims Post-Katrina
parts.body: In dealing with Hurricane Katrina claims, State Farm and some insurance companies were accused of encouraging improper handling of damage claims, often shifting the burden of proof to policyholders instead of determining what damage was caused by wind or water. The anti-concurrent causation clause complicated claims by excluding coverage if water damage occurred concurrent with wind. Litigation arose, with courts sometimes ruling against State Farm's perspective, demanding they pay for wind damage that could be proven even if there was concurrent flood damage. Despite evidence of wind damage, State Farm denied many claims citing lack of proof of exclusive wind damage, leading to numerous unsettled claims and public frustration. State Farm attempted to critique their processes openly in response to public backlash. Despite some courts agreeing that anti-concurrent causation clauses were valid, this resulted in ambiguity and claims being denied in unclear cases, leaving policyholders uncompensated even when substantial wind damage evidence existed. Association between poor handling of Hurricane Katrina claims and past incidents, such as tornado damage claims in Oklahoma, showed patterns of manipulation by hiring engineering firms to reflect favorable outcomes for insurers. Critics argued these practices aimed to exploit loopholes, resulting in insurance companies benefitting while leaving policyholders at a disadvantage, affecting trust in insurance providers.

parts.title: Unfair Insurance Fraud Practices
parts.body: Insurance companies' fight against fraud often leads to unfair practices against consumers. Red flags often treat legitimate claims as fraud. Adjusters and SIUs are trained to suspect rather than honor claims. Technology aids in flagging suspicious claims, but many legitimate ones get caught in this net. Erie Insurance and MetLife use data mining to tag fraudulent claims and insurance experts admit systems are inexact.

parts.title: Effectiveness of Insurance Regulation and Industry Influence
parts.body: In this chunk, the effectiveness of insurance regulation is discussed, focusing on issues surrounding claims practices and regulatory influence. Insurance companies often gain regulatory favor due to their significant political contributions and organizational influence. State regulators are more effective at solvency and rate regulation rather than addressing unfair claims practices. A common issue is the under-resourced market conduct regulation, which often does not adequately address the "delay, deny, defend" strategies used by insurance companies in claims handling. Most state insurance departments devote less than 5% of their staff to market conduct issues and about 13% to consumer affairs, which encompasses various problems beyond claims practices. Complaint handlers in many states manage excessively high caseloads, inhibiting effective processing of consumer grievances. Industry influence complicates regulatory processes further, with a revolving door between former regulatory heads and leadership positions within the insurance industry, exemplified by reasons like financial entanglements and strategic lobbying efforts.

parts.title: 9/11 Insurance Dispute
parts.body: In the aftermath of 9/11, a significant legal dispute arose between Silverstein and his insurance companies regarding how the attack was officially categorized under insurance policies. The crux of the debate was whether the attack constituted a single "occurrence," which would limit Silverstein's insurance payout to $3.5 billion, or two separate incidents, which could double the recovery amount to $7 billion. This legal battle involved extensive litigation and numerous lawyers, with courts eventually issuing different decisions based on the specific language of various policies involved. This emphasizes the complexity and importance of policy wording in insurance claims with catastrophic events.
